author: Zubeda Hamid
text:
Surveillance measures put in place to prevent the entry of the Zika virus continue in Tamil Nadu, even as media reports say Bangladesh reported one sample from a patient testing positive. The Union Health Ministry will start random testing for the virus in patients who show viral fever-like symptoms by the end of April, a media report has said.

Diagnostic facilities to test for the virus are now available in Tamil Nadu, said Director of Public Health K. Kolandaisamy, with the King Institute of Preventive Medicine having acquired testing kits.

“At airports and sea ports, we are continuing with our Aedes-free campaign to eradicate mosquito breeding sources. With construction going on in several areas, this is especially important,” said Dr. Kolandaisamy. A health information post continues to function at the airport, he said. The virus, spread over parts of South America, is transmitted through the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito, which also transmits dengue.

While the illness caused by the virus is reported to be a mild fever, it is said to be associated with microcephaly – where babies are born with an abnormally small head.

Routine checks are continuing on ships and aircraft, Dr. Kolandaisamy said. Passengers who have returned from Zika hotspots are being tracked and monitored. “We are ensuring that the areas they are live in are completely Aedes-free,” he said.

“The only cause for concern when it comes to this virus is its link with microcephaly,” he said.

At any given point, there are an estimated 5 to 6 lakh pregnant women in Tamil Nadu.

Dengue incidence

Fever surveillance is continuing, Dr. Kolandaisamy said. Local body and Corporation employees are performing household checks to eradicate breeding sources. “With an increase in experience and resources, we have managed to control dengue too,” he said.

Pockets for dengue in the State include Tirupur, Tirunelveli and Thoothukudi districts, but the virus is being managed, he said. “In Tirupur, we have had no cases for two months now,” he said.

title: Zika test kits available with King Institute
